Robert de Hangest; Beauvais Cathedral; Brölemann sale at Sotheby's, 5 May 1926, lot 161; Otto F. Ege (1888-1951); acquired (as gift from class of 1936?) by Rutgers' Douglass Library; transfer in 1997. Earlier call number (Douglass Library): ND3375.F889. Related leaves exist in various institutions.
authorized_label: Robert de Hangest;Beauvais Cathedral;Henri Auguste Brölemann;Otto Ege

name_as_recorded: Rolandus de Asillo filius ser Odarici
Rosenthal, antiquarian bookdealer in Munich; Adolph Sutro (1830-1898), mayor of San Francisco.
Second artist of the Hours of Cecilia Gonzaga, New York, Morgan Library M 454 (Alexander c. 2010, pp. 65–66).

Signature Ann MoneyIon fol. 84r, probably eighteenth-century; George C. Thomas (1839-1909), banker and picture collector; his sale, Philadelphia, 18 November 1924, lot 205; C. L. Ricketts; acquired by the Lilly Library with the Ricketts Collection in 1961.
authorized_label: Ann Moneylon;George C. Thomas;Coella Lindsay Ricketts

name_as_recorded: Similar to the scribe of the Hours of Étienne Chevalier

Sir Thomas Phillips (1792-1872), part of his MS 22254; bought by Tregaskis at the Phillips sale, Sotheby's, 25 April 1911, lot 391; Tregaskis cat. 706 (1911), no. 17, and cat. 720 (1912), no 36; bought by C. L. Ricketts, and acquired by the Lilly Library with the Ricketts Collection in 1961.

Sold at Sotheby’s, 8 July 1974, lot 93; Eric Sexton (1902-1980), with his bookplate; his sale, Christie’s, New York, 22 May 1981, lot 9; Laurence Witten cat. 18 (1983), no. 48; Ruth E. Adomeit (1910-1996), bequeathed by her to the Lilly Library.
authorized_label: Eric Hyde Lord Sexton;Ruth E. Adomeit

name_as_recorded: Southeby's, 28 May 1934, lot 100, and then Dawson of Los Angeles?; Otto F. Ege (1888-1951); acquired (as gift from class of 1936?) by Rutgers' Douglass Library; transfer in 1997. Earlier call number (Douglass Library): ND3395.T2. Related leaf: Columbia University, Rare Book and Manuscript Library Med/Ren Frag. 4.

St Emmeram, Regensburg, a Benedictine monastery founded in 739 and suppressed in 1802; Sir Thomas Phillips (1792-1872), his MS 6924, bought from the London bookseller Thomas Thorpe, c.1832; Messrs. W.H. Robinson, who bought the residue of the Phillips library in 1945-46; sold by them to George A. Poole in 1947, and acquired by the Lilly Library with the Poole Collection in 1958.
Survived as part of a binding with title "Bulle unionis fratrum minorum"; acquired in 2000 from H.P. Kraus.
Survived as part of a binding; "From Drew T[heological]. Seminary, March 31--1893." Earlier call number: Ac. 3660.
Survived as part of a binding; acquired from H.P. Kraus by Karl F. Morrison (b. 1936); his gift in 2003.
Survived as part of a binding; acquired in 2000 from H.P. Kraus.
Survived as part of a binding?; probably in library for many decades.

The Abbey of St-Vaast in Arras; Sir Thomas Phillips (1792-1872), part of his MS 22229; from the collection of specimen leaves formed by Messrs. W.H. Robinson, who bought the residue of the Phillips Library in 1945-46, sold by them to George A. Poole in 1947, and acquired by the Lilly Library with the Poole Collection in 1958.
authorized_label: Abbey of St. Vaast;George Amos Poole

name_as_recorded: The Augustinian nunnery of Sankt Maria Magdalena, Hildesheim, founded 1224 and suppressed at the Reformation; sale by Karl & Faber, Munich, 25 June 1963, lot 4; acquired by the Lilly Library from Lathrop Harper, New York, 1968.
authorized_label: Sankt Maria Magdalena, Hildesheim;Lathrop C. Harper, Inc.

name_as_recorded: The Earl of Hopetoun sale (London, 1889, n. 402) to Matthews. Given to the Grolier Club in 1905 by Daniel B. Fearing.
authorized_label: John Hope, 1st Marquess of Linlithgow;Daniel B. Fearing

name_as_recorded: The Hungerford Hours was illuminated by the same artist as a Psalter at Schloss Herdringen in Germany, MS 8 (Sandler 1986, p. 89, no. 81).
The Olivetan abbey of Santi Angelo e Nicolò in Villanova Sillaro, near Lodi; C. L. Ricketts, and acquired by the Lilly Library with the Ricketts Collection in 1961.
authorized_label: Santi Michele Arcangelo e Nicola Vescovo church;Coella Lindsay Ricketts

name_as_recorded: The abbey of Saint Maximin in Treir (founded c. 500, supressed 1802); Fritz Rörig (1882-1952), of Berlin, bought in Keil (where he taught 1923-35); bought from his widow in 1953 by H.P. Kraus and sold by him in January 1954 to George A. Poole; acquired by the Lilly Library with the Poole Collection in 1958.
authorized_label: St. Maximin's Abbey;Fritz Rörig;George Amos Poole

name_as_recorded: The dean of Lu"kirch; Carthusians of Buxheim (cf. note on f. i verso), with "N. 175" in ink on f. 1 and on the spine; "386" also on the spine; Hugo, Graf von Waldbott-Basenheim (Munich, 20 Sept. 1883, lot 2616); Adolph Sutro (1830-1898), mayor of S. F.
authorized_label: Dean of Lukirch;Buxheim Charterhouse;Hugo Philipp Waldbott-Bassenheim;Adolph Sutro

name_as_recorded: The ducal library of Arenberg, Brussels, probably acquired by Duc Engelbert-Auguste d'Arenberg (1824-1875); one of two leaves sold by the tenth duke, Engelbert-Charles d'Arenberg (1899-1974), Hauswedell, Hamburg, Auktion 52-53, April 1953, lot 7a; bought in February 1954 by George A. Poole from W.H. Schab, New York dealer, and acquired by the Lilly Library with the Poole Collection in 1958.
authorized_label: Engelbert, 8th Duke of Arenberg;Engelbert Charles, 10th Duke of Arenberg;George Amos Poole

name_as_recorded: The ms. has a contemporary inscription: Iste libellus est fratris thomassurii.

The verso of f. 1 (the leaf with the red letter C) bears note in a s. XVIII hand: "Mr. John Higges's Diary 1720-1727." Directly above this is a later note that reads: "I bought this Diary at a sale of <?> Percy's MSS and sold it to a descendant of Higgi."

This collection of English binding fragments was given to NYU in 1884 by Homer L. Bartlett (b. 1858), who graduated in that year from NYU with a degree in Science and Civil Engineering; by 1902, he was second vice-president of the Eastern District Savings Bank.
Thomas Lye, vicar of Magna Wolford
Tiptoft Master, in the style of. The illumination is close to that of the Paduan painter of the 1460s known as the Tiptoft Master
Traces of a library stamp on f. 1. Acquired from Robson and Kerslake (according to de Ricci) by Daniel B. Fearing of Newport, Rhode Island who gave it to the Grolier Club in 1908.

Unknown. Apparently purchased from Phillip Pirages, November 1987. From the collection of Karen Keel Gould (1946-2012) Gift of Lewis Gould to the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in 2012 in his wife's memory.

Unknown. Purchased by Karen Gould (1946-2012). Gift of Lewis Gould to the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in 2012 in his wife's memory.
Urbano, son of Giovanni Jacopo degli Irbani
V. M. Voynich (1865-1930), Polish revolutionary and bookseller, who gave it to C. L. Ricketts; acquired by the Lilly Library with the Ricketts Collection in 1961.

Verona, Biblioteca Comunale, ms. 3034, written in scriptorium of Archdeacon Pacificus; survived as part of a binding repair; acquired in 1991 from P. Pirages. Related item (codex with repairs from same manuscript): ferial Psalter and Hymnal from the Abbey of San Zeno Maggiore, Yale MS 744.
authorized_label: Biblioteca civica di Verona;Phillip J. Pirages Fine Books & Manuscripts

name_as_recorded: William Young Ottley (1771-1836) probably; John Rushout, second Baron Northwick (1770-1859); Northwick Park sale, Sotheby’s, 21 May 1928, part of lot 14; C. L. Ricketts, and acquired by the Lilly Library with the Ricketts Collection in 1961.
authorized_label: William Young Ottley;John Rushout, 2nd Baron Northwick;Coella Lindsay Ricketts

name_as_recorded: Written by Iodocus Grebel at Lucerne in 1617. Front pastedown bears a note in pencil: "bought at Lucerne 21 June 1884;" and a book seller or dealer description labeled "110." Given to GTS by Guild of Scholars in 1948, per typed card and bookplate.

Written in 1505 for Giovanni Pietro Visconti (1478-1515), provost of Milan cathedral (see below); Oliver Rogers Barrett (1873-1950), Chicago attorney, who gave it to C. L. Ricketts in 1918; acquired by the Lilly Library with the Ricketts Collection in 1961.
authorized_label: Giovanni Pietro Visconti;Oliver R. Barrett;Coella Lindsay Ricketts

name_as_recorded: Written in France (possibly northern?) s. XIV (early in the century according to De Ricci). Obtained by General Theological Seminary in 1912 from Joseph (Giuseppe) Martini (1870-1944), as reported by De Ricci.
Written in France in the fourth quarter of the fifteenth century. The ownership portrait on f. 29 and the feminine forms in several prayers indicate that the book was made for a woman.
Written in Spain in the sixteenth century. A typed description of unknown origin attached to front pastedown suggests that the manuscript was written by an Italian scribe about 1500.

Written in the third quarter of the fifteenth century in France for use in England. Apparently in the hands of English Protestants at some point in the s. XVI#^2# (see notes on calendar). Obtained by General Theological Seminary from P.M. Barnard, as reported by De Ricci.
Zucchero Bencivenni, translator from French to Italian
